axioms.explanation: Prefer the explanation that requires the fewest assumptions while still accounting for all observed phenomena.
Eliminate steps that do not contribute to the outcome or introduce unnecessary complexity.
Select the smallest set of premises that still yield the intended conclusion.

paradoxes.explanation: A statement that refers to itself in a way that creates a contradiction, e.g., 'This statement is false.'
Explores whether an object that has had all its components replaced remains fundamentally the same object.
A logical inconsistency arising from self-reference: the barber shaves everyone who does not shave themselves—does he shave himself?
Challenges motion by arguing that an arrow in flight is motionless at any single instant in time.
A decision theory paradox involving prediction, free will, and expected utility.
Observing a non-black non-raven (e.g., a green apple) supports the hypothesis that all ravens are black—challenging intuitive logic.
If removing one grain from a heap still leaves a heap, when does it stop being a heap? Tests vague predicates and boundary logic.
An object or information is sent back in time and becomes the cause of itself—raising questions about origin and causality.
Can an omnipotent being create a stone so heavy that it cannot lift it? Challenges the coherence of absolute power.
A prisoner is told he will be hanged unexpectedly, but logical deduction seems to prevent the surprise—yet the execution still surprises him.
